[h1] I think it's safe to buy now [/h1]

What can you say man, it's Oblivion. Take one of the greatest video games ever made, slap a fresh coat of paint on it, make some modest QOL improvements/modernizations, and the result is...a really damn good video game! Oblivion is in my top 5 favorite video games of all time, so when I heard it was getting a remaster (and let's be real, we all heard, it was the worst kept secret in gaming), I said shut up and take my money and was in there day 1, because I am what is known in the games business as a "mark." Day 1 was almost 8 months ago at this point, so why has it taken me so long to write this review? Well, I told myself that I would wait to review Oblivion until I felt I had "finished" it, but in hindsight that's kind of silly, isn't it? Because finishing Oblivion is a monster undertaking, at the time of writing I am 85 hours deep into this game, I have finished the main questline, the Knights of the Nine questline, and most (but not all!) of the Fighter's Guild and Thieves Guild questlines. I have not started the Mages Guild or Dark Brotherhood questlines, nor have I even set foot in the Shivering Isles. There is [b] easily [/b] 120+ hours of content here, and for a relatively modest $49.99 ($59.99 for the deluxe edition which comes with a couple new quests and some sick-ass armor that I highly recommend), safe to say your dollar will go pretty far with this one even at full asking price, but of course you're more than welcome to wait for a sale or play it on Game Pass (assuming you haven't canceled it yet).

You might look at my progress and say, "gee, you haven't gotten very far, just what have you been doing all this time?" Just taking it all in, man. This is one of the most gorgeous video games I have ever played. I don't know if it's the [i] biggest [/i] remaster of all time, but I struggle to think of one that was bigger. This is a top-to-bottom visual overhaul, and it just looks so damn good. For the vast majority of my playthrough I wasn't really fast-traveling, just hopping on my horse and soaking in the new-and-improved Cyrodiil, wandering around the map and just seeing where the adventure took me. It's a rare gift to be able to experience one of your favorite games for the first time *again*, and man, what a great thing; there were some moments where I would take in a particularly breathtaking vista and actually get a little emotional, and all I could think was, "Those madmen. They actually did it."

And yeah, in this day and age, any time Bethesda does something that isn't some kind of massive f*ck-up you have to celebrate it. In the early days post-launch this game was full of that Bethesda Magic (derogatory), and some of the post-launch patches actually made performance [i] worse, [/i] to the point that I had to put the game down for a while because it was crashing so frequently. However, with this current version, v.1.5 or whatever we're on now, I feel confident in saying that the game is [i] mostly [/i] fixed, I'm playing on an AMD Radeon 6950 XT, and after a LOT of tinkering, I've managed to get the game running at a stable 60 fps on high settings, 3k resolution, FSR and ray tracing turned off. As an aside, it says this game is Steam Deck verified and I don't buy that for a moment, when I tried it on Deck, cloud saves were completely busted, but hey if I [b] could [/b] import my save data I'm sure I would have enjoyed playing for 30 minutes at 480p before my battery died.

So to sum up, yeah man, Oblivion is a great game and this is a great remaster. If you've never played Oblivion before, this is the definitive way to experience the game. I prefer it to Skyrim, I think it has better quest design, plus a quirky charm and tongue-in-cheek sense of humor that's missing from that later game. It's a good value for the price, and after some patches I'm confident in saying they finally got the damn thing working and running smoothly. Well...smooth for a Bethesda game at least, everything's relative. If you love the Elder Scrolls, if you love RPGs, you'll love Oblivion Remastered.

The greatest classic has earned its well-deserved rebirth

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was and remains my favorite childhood game. I eagerly awaited this remaster, fearing disappointment, but the developers not only met my expectations — they exceeded them. This isn't just another “upscaled” game, it's a love letter to fans and the perfect way for a new generation to get acquainted with one of the greatest RPGs in history.

What's brilliantly done:
1. Visuals and atmosphere:
The most obvious and impressive change. The game has gained incredibly detailed 4K textures that have enriched its unique artistic style rather than killing it. The forests around Cheydinhal are still magical and bright, but now every leaf and every blade of grass is rendered in detail. The moss-covered ruins, the Mages Guild armor, the characters' faces — everything looks modern, yet retains that slightly carnivalesque but charming aesthetic of 2006. The remaster makes good use of modern lighting and HDR: the sunsets over the Golden Shore make you want to turn off the interface and just watch, and the caves and dungeons are finally truly dark and scary, where you can't do without a torch or the Light spell.

2. Technical revival: Stability and comfort
The original Oblivion was famous for its bugs, which became part of folklore. Here, you get rock-solid 60 FPS stability (with an option to unlock the frame rate), no crashes during fast travel, and, thank Akatosh, the famous “save bloat” (swelling of save files) that killed playability during long sessions has been fixed. Loading times between locations have been reduced to 2-3 seconds. This is the game you can now play without having to fight its technical imperfections.

3. Gameplay: The convenience of the new era
The remaster has carefully preserved the gameplay foundation, but added a host of quality-of-life improvements:

Improved interface: It is now adaptive for large screens, easy to customize, and the spell/item wheel has become more intuitive.

Modern crafting system: Alchemy and enchanting have become more convenient, with clear menus and filters.

Revamped achievement system: New, interesting challenges have been added that encourage exploration of every corner of Tamriel.

4. Sound and Music: Timeless Classics
The soundtrack has been remastered and sounds clean and powerful. Jeremy Soule's familiar themes, from the epic intro to the peaceful music in the forests, strike a chord with renewed force. The sounds of swords, spells, and the cries of the Dremor in the Gates of the Abyss have all gained new depth without losing their original “crystal clarity.”

What remains “old school” (and that's a good thing!):
The developers did not “fix” what fans love about the original. Enemy levels still scale with yours, which may not appeal to everyone, but it's part of the spirit of Oblivion. The famous skill-based leveling system is also still there — it's not perfect, but for purists, it's an important part of the experience. And yes, some of the dialogue and facial animations are the same, which makes them even more nostalgic against the backdrop of sparkling new textures.

Verdict:
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered is a prime example of how remasters should be done. It doesn't redraw the game from scratch, losing its soul, but carefully restores it, emphasizing all its strengths and smoothing out technical rough edges.

For fans of the original: This is the perfect excuse to return to Cyrodiil. You'll be amazed by the beauty of this world all over again, just like the first time, but with the comforts of 2024.

For new players: If you've played Skyrim and want to understand where the series' roots lie, this is your best entry point. A deep spell system, flexible leveling, unforgettable guild questlines (especially the Dark Brotherhood!), and a true high fantasy atmosphere await you.

Time has not been kind to many games of that era, but the development team has given Oblivion immortality. This is not just a nostalgic trip, it is a full-fledged, living, breathing adventure that can still give many modern RPGs a run for their money.

Spend a coin on the guard and immerse yourself in this world. You won't regret it.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered brings one of Bethesda’s most celebrated RPGs into the modern era. It keeps the heart of the 2006 classic—freedom, exploration, and deep role-playing—while refreshing the visuals, performance, and interface for new systems. The remaster doesn’t reinvent the game, but it finally makes Cyrodiil look the way nostalgia remembers it.

Gameplay remains nearly identical to the original. Players create their own hero, escape the Imperial City’s prison, and enter a massive open world full of quests, factions, and dungeons. The mix of real-time combat, character development through use, and open choice still feels liberating. Despite its age, few RPGs offer this level of freedom and personality.

The new version upgrades visuals across the board. Lighting, textures, and draw distance are vastly improved, and character models look sharper without losing their original style. Weather effects, reflections, and foliage density give the world new life. It’s still unmistakably Oblivion, but finally without the heavy blur and stiff animations of 2006.

Performance is mixed but generally solid. On modern consoles it runs smoothly at high resolutions, though PC players report occasional frame drops and stutters. The menus and UI are reworked for cleaner navigation, and controller layouts feel natural. Loading times are also much shorter, making fast travel and exploration faster.

The inclusion of Shivering Isles and Knights of the Nine means the full experience is here. Combined with hundreds of side quests and guild storylines, the content remains enormous. The quest writing still shines, especially in the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves Guild arcs—proof of how strong the original design was.

Audio has been lightly remastered rather than replaced. Jeremy Soule’s orchestral soundtrack still captures the grandeur of Tamriel, and ambient effects sound clearer with modern mixing. Voice work remains dated but nostalgic, adding charm more than distraction.

Overall, Oblivion Remastered succeeds at preserving a classic while modernizing just enough to make it comfortable to play again. It doesn’t fix every legacy flaw—combat and AI still feel old—but the magic of exploration, discovery, and freedom remains fully intact. For fans of open-world RPGs, it’s the best way to experience one of the genre’s defining worlds.

Blivvy Remastered is wonderful. The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was always a fantastic Elder Scrolls game, and now it's extra-gorgeous. This is actually charming, in a nostalgic/historical way.  Menues are NOT console-ized as they were in Skyrim. Gameplay and interactions are improved over Morrowind, but still keep Morrowind's origin in their design (such as Persuasion still being a feature with any NPC you talk to).

This takes places in the province of Cyrodill, and as such is lush with normal (to IRL) green vegetation; lots of grass. The ES game Oblivion is classic high-fantasy style (where my beloved Morrowind was much more unique & weird, and Skyrim was snow & Viking-themed with the Nords).

I especially like how you can have 1 spell ready to cast with C at any time, while you are holding weapons.  In Morrowind you had to switch between weapons mode and spell casting mode.  In Skyrim you had to select what was in each hand, with perks to determine how well you can 'perform'.

As with Elder Scrolls games, it's completely and entirely open world; go anywhere and do whatever you want at any time. You certainly don't have to be a do-gooder knight; joining the Dark Brotherhood of assassins, the Thieves Guild, and/or becoming a vampire are options for you.  The story progression has you entering several Oblivion portals into a Hell-like dimension where you make your way through the fiery land and to the top of a metal tower facility to destroy it and thus close the portal (where the Oblivion denizens are invading Cyrodill from)... this can be ignored if you don't want to follow the main story.

As with every Elder Scrolls game there are mods!  The OG Oblivion mods don't work, so there aren't *that* many but there are still plenty.

I for instance didn't love the changes to the leveling system (I know, I'm crazy, but I was fond of the complexity of the old system and the idea of having to plan your character to be able to maximise him--something about it fed my OCD), but what you have to remember is that, as with any moddable Bethesda RPG, [b]nothing about the game is set in stone thanks to the modding community[/b].

What's important to know here, as a remaster, is that the game remains very faithful to its original iteration, which is awesome because the original Oblivion is a great game, and many of us playing this version will play it for that nostalgia.

So, friends, once again we delve into the jaws of Oblivion!

I love Oblivion, but I do not like this remaster. It introduces more bugs than it fixes, it eats up a whopping 110 more GB than the original, and for every thoughtful design change (such as the tweaks to leveling to address The Leveling Problem), the devs made two more annoying or obtuse design changes (most notably in the UI and menus, by adding additional submenus, requiring additional keystrokes to access crucial stat information, or removing much-needed organizational subcategories in the inventory panes). While the graphics are overall improved, this comes at the cost of performance on more modest PC setups compared to the original. And on a personal note, part of the charm of Oldblivion came from the uncanny character models and the half-dozen voice actors carrying 99% of the game's dialogue on their gigachad shoulders -- the juxtaposition of picturesque environments with goofy-looking creatures and characters. In updating the visuals and audios, some of the magic is lost, for me. Moreover, Oblivion was already a clearly imperfect game -- from its wobbly writing to its pendulum-swing dfficulty curve to its bug-ridden moment-to-moment experience -- and the remaster does very little to address some well-documented problems. For example, proposing a solution to The Leveling Problem does not fully address The Level-Scaling Problem. 

In short, if you are trying to choose between the old and the new, just buy Oldblivion. It is much cheaper (especially when on sale), and at least when the experience becomes completely jank and broken, you are getting what you paid for from a 2006-era game, as opposed to feeling cheated by a modern remaster that sadly fails to "master" much of the original's mechanics, systems, or most importantly, its spirit.

[i]The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion[/i] was perhaps one of my favorite games as a young teenager. I had played it on my Xbox 360 while my dad watched and it was also perhaps the game that got me into hunting for achievements, as it was the first game I ever 100% completed. People can say what they want about Bethesda now, I mostly agree with the criticisms, but I think their older titles had something special about them that they fail to replicate now with their newer ideas. So much so that I think more people are concerned about [i]The Elder Scrolls: VI[/i] than there are people actually anticipating its release. Bethesda has not done a good job lately in securing their community, especially with what happened with [i]Starfield[/i] being so dull.

And the remastering of this game proves why that is. This is a prime example of "UE5 slop" that you might often see online being applied to games designed in the Unreal Engine. [i]Borderlands 4[/i] had a similar release strategy where the developers release it to the store and ignore feedback and criticism about bad performance until they start realizing that the player base was right the whole time and their continuous lying wasn't fooling anybody into thinking that all they had to do was enable DLSS. Bethesda, however; released a low effort project, secured their money, and seemingly already abandoned the game. They are somehow worse than Gearbox and Randy Pitchford in that case because at least they went back on their laurels to try and fix BL4. 

It isn't just an example of UE5 slop, it's also been woke-ified, where as early as the character customization screen you see the terrible "body type" gender selector instead of what existed before where it was actually male and female genders. This is partly why people have lost hope for Bethesda and any future [i]Fallout[/i] or [i]Elder Scrolls[/i] titles. They have lost the plot in a number of ways. I shouldn't have to install a mod to add proper gender to my character so that I am not running around as a "body type 1" and my romanced NPC isn't known as a "body type 2" or something while the tourists continue to complain about gender and we have to continue pandering to their perpetually offended sensibilities. 

Unfortunately, it became too late for me to refund the game after two hours of playtime otherwise I wish I could have saved the $50 USD. It isn't that the game runs bad for me on my RTX 5090, it's that we can't trust that Bethesda did not implement or change other aspects of the original game to oblige an agenda that the industry continues to push. You would expect that the remastered version of the original would still keep much of the original the same, but with better graphics and perhaps some important QoL changes. 

To make matters worse, Bethesda mentioned that they were not going to officially support modded content, which is heresy coming from them when their video games have always supported modding, and mods could have, yet again, fixed this game and its issues. 

The only thing that stayed true to the original experience? The game, while having a huge map to explore and plenty of quests to do, has a lackluster variety of enemies and is on a sort of table where, as you level up, it moves away from spawning wolves to now spawning bears, completely removing lower level creatures from the map or just having them scale to you. You can easily get distracted by the open world and side quest content and go back into the main story and find yourself fighting against powerful atronachs while the friendly guards around you are slaughtered because they did not scale to your level. This was actually an issue with the original Oblivion and you had to play it a certain way if you didn't want to screw yourself over. I wonder if Oblivion is a game that could actually hold up to modern standards for video gaming, and I'm actually not too sure now that I think of it. 

They "revamped" the leveling experience at least so that you didn't screw yourself over that way, but, even still, this is a disappointing remastering of a once great video game in the [i]Elder Scrolls[/i] franchise. It's a lazy, overpriced cash grab that should really serve to hurt Bethesda's reputation more than it helps it.

Lastly, the changes to the levelling system make the game very unbalanced. Unlike the original where only major skills contribute to xp gain, in the remaster all skills contribute to xp gain. This causes your character to level up way too quickly, making you miss out on entire tiers of loot and enemies.

If you just want to experience Oblivion with nice graphics and don't mind performance issues, bugs and imbalances, this remaster is fine. But if you want a more complete experience, I would recommend you wait for Skyblivion or just stick with the original game.
